lines.text: What's the matter with your clothes?
You did the laundry.
Poor Bob. I almost felt sorry for him. Almost.
[hearing the doorbell ring]

[sweetly]
Would somebody please get the door?
[doorbell continues ringing]

[angry]
WOULD SOMEBODY PLEASE GET THE GODDAMN DOOR?
You're still the butler - so get to work!
I may be the butler, but I'm NOT the maid!
You give men what they want, and then they don't want it anymore.
That's your wife, too bad.
I have been sorry my whole life, and from the looks of it, so have you.

*one*, a home, that is my castle; *two*, a family, that is loving and devoted; *three*, a successful career that I worked very hard to maintain; and *four*, the freedom to enjoy the fruits of my labor. But when it comes to liabillities, I have only one.
[shouts]
Thats you, Ruth! And I'm not gonna let you ruin everything
[yells]

I've worked so hard for! You're a bad mother, a lousy wife, and a terrible cook! In fact, have you looked in a *mirror* recently? I don't even you're a woman. You know what you are? You're a *she-devil*!
What about our clothes?
Gone.
What about my toys?
Gone.
What about my tapes?
Gone, everything is gone.
So, are you saying she was... promiscuous?
"Promiscuous"? She was a teen-aged tramp; she couldn't get enough! She would do it anywhere, anytime, and with anyone! She got knocked up when she was sixteen.
Knocked up?
Well, she couldn't take care of it! Had to give that cute little baby boy up for adoption!
So you're saying there's a missing member of the Fisher royal clan?
Royal my ass! Her father was a kosher butcher from Hoboken! A lovely man!
I'm taking back control of my life, Bob! As long as you're all under my roof things will be done *my* way, starting *now*!
Urrrrghhhh!
[throws up on the carpet and staggers away]
Ute, where are you going?
I took this job because I only had to cook and clean for one person and one dog. Then I get the mother, the lover, his kids and their dog. Miss Fisher, up with this bullshit I will not put. I quit!
Fuzzy has just shit on the carpet.

[to Ruth]
I've always been totally honest with you.

[to Ruth]
What's going on between me and Mary is purely professional.
Andy, Nicolette, this is your new home.

[to Mary]
Oh, I'm so sorry.
Who let you in here?
God damn it! Rose!
[Mary has stormed out of the car after discovering that he's been sleeping with Olivia]
Mary! You know you're the only woman I've ever been faithful to?

[narrating]
Some women are born beautiful. They make it look easy. But most women have to put a little time and effort into their appearance, and then there are those of us who need all the help we can get, like me.
[last lines]
Please, call me Mary.
I hate to say "I told you so..."
But you just did, didn't you?
Okay Ruth, I'll give you a few days, then you've got to come back for the kids. Where can I reach you?
I'm not coming back, Bob, they'll have a much better life here with you.
Wait a minute, Ruth, where're you going?
I don't know, Bob, into my future I guess.

I would have to get used to being alone now. It's not easy for a mother to be separated from her children. I'll bet Mary Fisher's mother feels the same way. Maybe I can help old Mrs. Fisher get reacquainted with her daughter. But first, I would need a new name.

[switching the nursing home's sedatives with energy pills]
Mary Fisher's mother had been enjoying a long, untroubled sleep. It was time to wake her up.

[coaching the nursing home women in a game of soccer, jumping up and down]
Come on! Kick that ball! Yes, go! Come on Miss Zulinski!
What is going on here?
Oh, isn't it wonderful?
I know what you've been doing! The vitamins, the workouts, it's against the rules! I'm going to report you to Mrs. Trumper and then you'll be sorry.

Oh I don't think so, I HAVE been sorry my whole life and by the looks of it, so have you, so you do whatever you want. It's a shame though, Hooper, I always thought that women like us should stick together. Let's go! Kick that ball!

[picks up Mary Fisher's book]
Mary Fisher, any relation?
My daughter.
Oh how nice.
She's a slut. Bitch keeps me in this dogpound while she lives the life of a princess in her gar damn mansion!
Well that doesn't seem fair.
Yeah I ought to drop in on her one day, that'd scare the shit out of her.
You have rights, if you wanted to go see your daughter nobody could stop you.
I'm too old.
You are a mature and vibrant woman, and don't you let anybody tell you anything different.
Yeah? I suppose I could go on Sunday afternoon.
I'll put you on the train myself, and I'll even call ahead to make sure the butler knows you're coming.
Butler? I'll bet there's hanky panky there.
Well there's only one way to find out.

[to Mary]
Go get a facial!
